That came out wrong...
This place is one of the best welding schools in the US.  one of our instructors ran the diablo canyon welding department,  also lol
Anything involving thin sheet metal is pretty mindblowing
Wow nice
Lemme guess. You're using Lincoln electric
The school has both but im a Lincoln fan
What's the other brand?
Miller
Ever tried a fronius?
That is something i have never heard of
Hahaha i thought so
Over here it's Lincoln, Miller, and Hobart for the budget friendly
Most advanced welding equipment you can get
Licoln can't hold a candle to that stuff
European company. Quite unusual to see in murica but some shops use it
It tends to be expensive. In turn you can use it for generations to come
Im on their website. It looks pretty nifty
Our workshop uses that stuff and i love it to bits
Take a look at their magic wave wig/mig/electro combi
The big thing here is engine drive units because of all the rural jobsites
Engine drive units? You mean the big block of metal in the engine core?
Its a giant welder with its own built in generator that can do every process except oxy welding
Fits in the bed of a truck so you can drive it anywhere
Ohh wow
Yeah logical step to make it self powered for that
But never thought of that since europ is not that rural. Even the rural areas are not the american kind of rural
They can run up to 40,000 for 100% duty cycle 27,000W diesel units
so not cheap
but some are only $5,000
I can imagine... i mean fronius has a battery powered welder... but that thing prolly has way less power
We have it but i haven't had the need to use it yat
*yet
The engine ones are designed for pipelines and railroads and such that wont leave the field for months at a time
I mean i play around with welding equip but i'm not that profecional with that stuff. I'm still an it guy

If you can kinda weld you are pretty much set for life, yeah thats prrobably why its $40,000

:ctwokinds-RainezZz:

Ah, seems I missed a conversation about welding. But to add my $0.02, yes, learning to weld proficiently is unbelievably lucrative. Pops used to teach welding at the high school level and made sure he got as many of his students as many certificates as
possible before they graduated. Kids left high school after taking his courses and went on to immediately get $40+ an hour jobs.
Now he teaches welding at the college level and he's working on coursework to teach students how to use automated welding machines so they can go out and get the jobs that robots replaced as well.
It's a pretty high demand field.  Since I haven't seen you since, congrats on your rollarcoaster pic
\o/ Thanks
:roller_coaster:

Yeah, he used to organize and participate in inter-state welding competitions for his students. They always got high marks in the end and a lot of his kids got jobs from being talent spotted at the events. If those kids followed through, they were set.
Plus if you do pipe or marine welding you can see 6 figures starting out
Yeah, last event he got an underwater welding company to come out with a giant tank and give demos on what goes on in the field.
Thats really cool

And the kids have a blast because every event is themed. Last one he did was Mad Max themed and the kids had two days to fabricate a working Mad Max go kart pretty much from scratch in their parking lot.
Example A: https://i.imgur.com/WpdNIpw.jpg
Thats awesome!  we mostly do trailers at our school seeing as its a structural certificate course

Hehehe, part of the competition judging was on structural soundness I suppose. The karts had to go through obstacle courses and survive rough terrain. Some were pretty good at installing proper suspension and making sure everything was tight.
Others however.... https://i.imgur.com/HxjY8IY.jpg
And of course we had some serious professionals show up as well https://i.imgur.com/CnbRGyN.jpg
That looks pretty fun.

Alas, he retired from high school. But he's trying to get the event to be a permanent fixture of his college so they have a central location every year instead of having it shift all around the states with varying levels of quality.
The ones that he doesn't host are very hit or miss. The one prior to this almost killed the program entirely because the school hosting it put zero fucking effort into it.
Events like that are great when you do them on site.  Our welding contest attracts businesses looking to hire right out of the course
